content:
Russia was also interested in expanding its influence in East Asia during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In particular, Russia was interested in gaining access to warm-water ports on the Pacific coast, which would allow it to expand its trade and military power in the region.

Russia's interest in Korea was primarily driven by its strategic and economic interests. Russia saw Korea as a potential ally in its efforts to expand its influence in East Asia and gain access to ports on the Pacific coast. Russia had also been involved in previous conflicts over Korea, including the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-1905, in which Japan emerged as the victor.

While Russia did not have immediate plans to invade Korea, it was certainly interested in maintaining its influence in the region and competing with Japan for control over Korea and other parts of East Asia. Ultimately, the struggle for influence in East Asia between Russia, Japan, and other imperial powers contributed to the tensions and conflicts that would lead to World War I and its aftermath.
